page.description: Open a set - primary table of set becomes primary table of session. TIP: It is generally better to use set.open_session().
page.syntax: as P = Open(C setname[,N file_open_mode|SQL::Arguments args[,C encryption key]])

argument.name: setname
argument.description: The name of a set. The extension ".set" is assumed.

argument.name: file_open_mode|SQL
argument.description: Optional. Determines the access privileges that apply to the open table file. You can use one of the following system variables:

argument.name: encryption
argument.description: Optional. Needed if the table has been encrypted, and the default encryption key has not been set (using the DEFAULT_ENCRYPTION_KEY_SET() function), of if the table was encrypted using a different encryption key than the default encryption key.

page.discussion: SET.OPEN()opens a set and returns a pointer to the set. Returns the pointer variable that references the set. See TABLE.OPEN() for a description of the Open Mode and Password parameters. Note : If you have set a Master Password for your database, and have encrypted tables using the Tools, Security menu, then the default encryption key is automatically set when the database is opened, and you do not need to specify the Password parameter when opening tables. TECHNICAL NOTE : If you use the SET.OPEN() method in a script attached to a button or event on a form, it will fail because SET.OPEN()tries to make the primary table of the set the primary table of the session. This is not possible, since the table (or primary table of the set) on which the Form is based is the primary table of session, and you cannot reset the primary table of a session for a Form. For this reason, the SET.OPEN_SESSION() method is more useful, because it can be called from an event on a form.
